data.text: bir-onceki-elbise-yikama-postu
When doing a multi-week tour, how do you go about washing your clothes?
merino tops which donâ€™t get smelly quickly and can be aired and reworn. On a 5 month trip, about once a month I hung out an extra day in a town with a laundromat or a backpackers hostel
data.author: Andrea Rose

data.text: merino wool clothing is perfect for bike trips!
data.author: Ronda King

data.text: are they very hot to wear in warm temps?
data.author: Marese Barry-Belanger

data.text: - have long sleeve heavy ones and short sleeve light ones and choose which I take. Iâ€™m in Australia and have worn my short sleeve ones in far north Queensland without a problem.
data.author: Andrea Rose

data.text: Every night in the sink or bucket, dry overnight. Wear again in the morning.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: Go to a laundromat. Use a washing machine then a dryer
data.author: Rick Shaffer

data.text: I often take them into the shower with me and use doctor bronners. Every once in a while I will do a real clean at a laundry
data.author: David Miller

data.text: I hand wash undies and socks and just air out everything else
data.author: Scout Ess

data.text: Laundromats. Failing that, sinks. Not complicated. Get one of these universal sink stoppers.
data.author: Marcos Litwikki

data.text: I washed my bike clothes in the hotel sink.
data.author: Steve Farmer

data.text: Sorry too high Jack this but I was wondering about a towel. Does anyone pack one. I packed a hand towel on my a short trip and the weather was cooler the towel pretty much stayed damp my entire ride
data.author: Tristan Grubb

data.text: i highly recommend a microfiber camp towel (decathlon has awesome cheap ones). I use them to roll my washed clothes and they dry overnight. I would not take a super large one
data.author: Megan Marie

data.text: I found the travel towels get whiffy after a short while, so I've been using a cotton sarong this trip and it works great and dries quickly. Has the added benefit of multiple uses.
data.author: Karen Thompson

data.text: hey Tristan, I use a sports towel. They are highly absorbent and dry really quickly.
data.author: Jerry Zmistowski

data.text: microfiber towels, or the more old-fashioned Pertex camping towels, pack down very small.
data.author: Mark Severs

data.text: I have a quick dry towel I got from REI. It weighs just a few ounces and does the job.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: the most important thing a traveler can carry is a towel ; Ford Perfect.
data.author: Mak McCjmak

data.text: have the same they are great
data.author: Alison Smith

data.text: in Australia we have a product called Robust Chux - usually used for wiping benches etc. They are mini and weigh almost nothing. Use one of these before using your pack towel to wipe excess moisture off skin and hair. Your pack towel will not stay drier. The Robust Chux dries easily and lasts almost indefinitely.
data.author: Susan Barber

data.text: I use my road runner fork bags to scrub and rinse my laundry. Easy as pie
data.author: Aj Sake

data.text: I bring quick dry clothes, especially underwear and socks. Wash in sink, squeeze, roll in microfiber towel to eliminate excess water. Ready to go in the morning.
data.author: Megan Marie

data.text: what about your cycle shorts that have padding, they surely take a long time to try ?
data.author: Steve Owen

data.text: yes, but I bring 2 pair and press the pad a lot with the absorbent towel. If they are still wet, I hang them off the bike or panniers while wearing pair #2
data.author: Megan Marie

data.text: thank youâ€¦. Now I have no excuse ðŸ˜‚
data.author: Steve Owen

data.text: Wash clothes when I shower or if I find a water tap handy... and if you look closely my laundry is drying all over my bike. Everything I have is quick dry, and I almost always hand wash.
data.author: Karen Thompson

data.text: If it's not too chilly, you can just put on still-wet clothes (Lycra and Helly Hansen-type stuff) and start pedalling - they'll be dry before you know it. Tie the rest on top of your panniers for a blow-dry.
data.author: Ed Tarwinski

data.text: Wash clothes, keep your beer cold, wash dishes, wash yourself. Multi purpose travel bucket
data.author: Lee Davis

data.text: yes, collapsible travel buckets are essential. So many uses.
data.author: Matthew Adams

data.author: Mark Steenson

data.text: that is crazy expensive. I bought a cheap dry bag and essentially used it the same way. The only difference I see between this and a dry bag is the wash board featured inside which does not seem worth it to me.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: it ok for me it worth it
data.author: Mark Steenson

data.text: if 50 bucks is crazy expensive you're in the wrong sport/hobby (cycling)
data.author: Matt von Asten

data.text: for a bag to wash clothes that is crazy expensive. I understand spending money on bike stuff, but not a bag that is just to wash clothes.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text:
think about your traveling by bike living on the bike long tours one way to save money in the long run is to use this ie I donâ€™t have to pay Landry mat services ever week in one month it paid for it self .. ps donâ€™t ask me what seat I use that scare you if you thought 50$ expensive https://infinitybikeseat.com/shop/infinity-e1x-series-seat lol
Elite Series Bike Seat â€“ E1X - Infinity Bike Seat

data.author: Mark Steenson

data.text: I bring Tide pods with me. Most hotels/motels/inns have laundry facilites
data.author: Sergio Armani

data.text: By hand if I have to
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: I used a small dry bag. Put in some water and soap and shake vigorously.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: I wash my bike clothes when I take a shower and just use the hand soap. If there are laundry facilities I have washer sheets. If camping, I tie a line from my bike to the tent if there are no trees available. I take everything in at night even if not dry because it will be even wetter in the morning if left out due to dew. If packed wet in the morning, it comes out when Iâ€™ve stopped for the day to dry or Iâ€™ve hung it from the bike during the day.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: What are washer sheets?
data.author: Scott Atwood

data.text: I got ecosa laundry detergent sheets. 1 sheet per load, no scent. Comes in 25 pack. Sheet dissolves in cold water. Someone gave me a detergent sheet on a tour last year when I found out all the laundromat had was scented detergent which bothers me.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: Thanks, I never heard of em'.
data.author: Scott Atwood

data.text:
these are the ones I use: https://www.tru.earth/Store/Tru-Earth-Eco-strips-Laundry-Detergent-FL-32?utm_source=google_shopping&utm_medium=cpc&utm_campaign=GS_fresh_linen&gclid=CjwKCAjwloCSBhAeEiwA3hVo_YJDnMdNvHVQN1xCv1Obd3FKO8m3uA8iHyVqWB7DGAzVMTBCMj-YiBoCKK4QAvD_BwE

data.author: Susan Barber

data.text: Hand laundry soap, like the old-time washerwomen used. Rinse, soap up, scrunch a bit, rinse again. Squeeze out, roll in camp towel, hang to dry. If you use quick drying material, your stuff will be ready by morning. On a long tour, an occasional laundromat will do a better job.
data.author: Mark Kennet

data.text: I bought a bag of soap flakes to take on my forthcoming trip
data.author: Ed Tarwinski

data.text: Hand wash or find a local laundry mat also a lot of campgrounds have laundry facilities
data.author: Gabe Gabe

data.text:
I seen these on Shark Tank a while ago... data.author: Andrew Neal

data.text: I take a bar of laundry soap and wash stuff in the basins in the toilet block of a campsite. I take about 10 metres of 2.5mm kernmantel string (sold in climbing and caving shops) as washing line and string it up to trees or whatever.
data.author: Mark Severs

data.text: Laundromat or hand wash the cycling kit.
data.author: Owen Nathan Tait

data.text: Laundromats, washing machines at hotels, washing machines at commercial campgrounds. And everything is dried in a dryer just like at home. Bike clothes arenâ€™t delicate and donâ€™t need to be treated like lingerie.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Laundromat or, very rarely, Iâ€™ll get a hotel that has laundry available.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I prefer to do it at a campground with laundry facilities. Otherwise Iâ€™ll stop at a laundromat. Very rarely Iâ€™ll stay at a hotel with laundry facIlities. Even more rare is staying with a WS host that will let me do laundry.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Anything under a week I don't do a wash. Instead, I do a major sponge bath every night. This also keeps your sleeping bag cleaner.
data.author: Gary Faryon

data.text: Rain
data.author: Carol Bailey Guziewski

data.text: By hand. I hang them out to dry over night.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: Ortlieb pannier can be used as a wash tub.
data.author: Tom Heutte

data.text: I have seen a lot of folks use rivers and other water sources.
data.author: Al Mcdonald

data.text: Ever been to a laundrette. You can even make your lunch there when its raining.
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: In a large heavy-duty dry bag in a size that suits you.
data.author: Colin M Boyle

data.text: In a Sea to summit kitchen sink
data.author: Paul Blood

data.text: Earth Breeze laundry detergent sheets helped me wash in the sink. So lightweight! One sheet is for a full load so I only used 1/4 at a time for my essentials until I got to an airbnb with a washer.
data.author: Faigy Grossman

data.text: Truck stops have facilities, if this hasn't been said.
data.author: Justin Morrison

data.text: I go to a laundromat and pretend I'm Nick Kamen.

data.text: Restroom sink, creek or leave out over night in the rain

data.text: Figure out what laundromat is in the local language. Google maps.

data.text: Rain works really well for me.

data.text: Both hand washing and laundromat.
